sn22.20:1.3.pli: Yopi hetu yopi paccayo rūpassa uppādāya, sopi anattā.
sn22.20:1.3.en: The cause and condition that gives rise to form is also not-self.

sn22.20:1.4.pli: Anattasambhūtaṁ, bhikkhave, rūpaṁ kuto attā bhavissati.
sn22.20:1.4.en: Since form is produced by what is not-self, how could it be self?

sn22.20:1.9.pli: Yopi hetu yopi paccayo viññāṇassa uppādāya, sopi anattā.
sn22.20:1.9.en: The cause and condition that gives rise to consciousness is also not-self.

sn22.20:1.10.pli: Anattasambhūtaṁ, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṁ kuto attā bhavissati.
sn22.20:1.10.en: Since consciousness is produced by what is not-self, how could it be self?

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 22
2. Impermanence
20. Not-Self With Its Cause

sn22.17:1.3.pli: Yadanattā taṁ ‘netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṁ.
sn22.17:1.3.en: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn22.17:1.8.pli: Yadanattā taṁ ‘netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṁ.
sn22.17:1.8.en: And what’s not-self should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

sn35.142:1.2.pli: Yopi hetu, yopi paccayo cakkhussa uppādāya, sopi anattā.
sn35.142:1.2.en: The cause and condition that gives rise to the eye is also not-self.

sn35.142:1.3.pli: Anattasambhūtaṁ, bhikkhave, cakkhu kuto attā bhavissati …pe…
sn35.142:1.3.en: Since the eye is produced by what is not-self, how could it be self?

sn35.142:1.8.pli: Yopi hetu yopi paccayo manassa uppādāya, sopi anattā.
sn35.142:1.8.en: The cause and condition that gives rise to the mind is also not-self.

sn35.142:1.9.pli: Anattasambhūto, bhikkhave, mano kuto attā bhavissati.
sn35.142:1.9.en: Since the mind is produced by what is not-self, how could it be self?

142. Interior and Cause Are Not-Self

sn22.59:2.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, rūpaṁ anattā, tasmā rūpaṁ ābādhāya saṁvattati, na ca labbhati rūpe:
sn22.59:2.4.en: But because form is not-self, it leads to affliction. And you can’t compel form:

sn22.59:5.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, viññāṇaṁ anattā, tasmā viññāṇaṁ ābādhāya saṁvattati, na ca labbhati viññāṇe:
sn22.59:5.4.en: But because consciousness is not-self, it leads to affliction. And you can’t compel consciousness:

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 22
6. Involvement
59. The Characteristic of Not-Self

sn35.164:1.3.pli: “Yo kho, koṭṭhika, anattā tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.164:1.3.en: “Koṭṭhita, you should give up desire for what is not-self.

sn35.164:1.9.pli: Yampidaṁ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tampi anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo …pe…
sn35.164:1.9.en: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also not-self: You should give up desire for it.

sn35.164:1.15.pli: yampidaṁ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṁ sukhaṁ vā dukkhaṁ vā adukkhamasukhaṁ vā tampi anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.164:1.15.en: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also not-self: you should give up desire for it.

sn35.164:1.16.pli: Yo kho, koṭṭhika, anattā, tatra te chando pahātabbo”ti.
sn35.164:1.16.en: Koṭṭhita, you should give up desire for what is not-self.”

sn22.68:1.4.pli: “Yo kho, bhikkhu, anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo”ti.
sn22.68:1.4.en: “Mendicant, give up desire for what is not-self.”

sn22.68:2.2.pli: “Rūpaṁ kho, bhante, anattā; tatra me chando pahātabbo.
sn22.68:2.2.en: “Sir, form is not-self; I should give up desire for it.

sn22.68:2.6.pli: viññāṇaṁ anattā; tatra me chando pahātabbo.
sn22.68:2.6.en: Consciousness is not-self; I should give up desire for it.

sn22.68:3.3.pli: Rūpaṁ kho, bhikkhu, anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn22.68:3.3.en: Form is not-self; you should give up desire for it.

sn22.68:3.7.pli: viññāṇaṁ anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn22.68:3.7.en: Consciousness is not-self; you should give up desire for it.

sn35.234:2.1.pli: “Yatheva nu kho, āvuso ānanda, ayaṁ kāyo bhagavatā anekapariyāyena akkhāto vivaṭo pakāsito:
sn35.234:2.1.en: “Reverend Ānanda, the Buddha has explained, opened, and illuminated in many ways how this body is not-self.

sn35.234:2.2.pli: ‘itipāyaṁ kāyo anattā’ti, sakkā evameva viññāṇaṁ pidaṁ ācikkhituṁ desetuṁ paññapetuṁ paṭṭhapetuṁ vivarituṁ vibhajituṁ uttānīkātuṁ: ‘itipidaṁ viññāṇaṁ anattā’”ti?
sn35.234:2.2.en: Is it possible to explain consciousness in the same way? To teach, assert, establish, open, analyze, and make it clear how consciousness is not-self?”

sn35.234:4.5.pli: “Imināpi kho etaṁ, āvuso, pariyāyena bhagavatā akkhātaṁ vivaṭaṁ pakāsitaṁ: ‘itipidaṁ viññāṇaṁ anattā’”ti …pe….
sn35.234:4.5.en: “In this way, too, it can be understood how consciousness is not-self.

sn35.234:6.5.pli: “Imināpi kho etaṁ, āvuso, pariyāyena bhagavatā akkhātaṁ vivaṭaṁ pakāsitaṁ: ‘itipidaṁ viññāṇaṁ anattā’ti.
sn35.234:6.5.en: “In this way, too, it can be understood how consciousness is not-self.
